div1.p: Reed comments on an earlier letter from Kean, briefly mentions his present occupation supervising a laboratory, and encourages Kean to write to him again soon. [Courtesy of The Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia Library]

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Jefferson Randolph Kean, November 11, 1896
div1.opener:
P.S. Please don't
let much time
intervene before
writing me another
of your charming
letters - W.R.
If I could
write so Enter-
tainingly I would
write to some
friend every
day of my life.
W.R.
WAR DEPARTMENT,
SURGEON GENERAL'S OFFICE,
ARMY MEDICAL MUSEUM AND LIBRARY,
WASHINGTON.
Nov. 11, 1896.
My dear Dr Kean:
div1.p:
If any one
had foretold that I would
so utterly neglect my much
esteemed friend, the Key West-
ian Post Surgeon, I would
have said indignantly, “man,
thou liest”! And yet! and
yet! how frail is poor
human nature! and how
evanescent are “good intentions”!
Certainly, I have contributed
my share to Hell's side-walks;
if there be sidewalks there.
Your charming letter, my dear
Doctor, of September 26th, now
lies open before me and silently
accuses me of my neglect and
general good-for-nothingness.
How much I enjoyed that letter,
I cannot tell begin to tell
you. To learn that you were
financially “busted” was
simply a giddy delight! for
I am always in that condition,
and “misery does so” &c
I knew that you could not be
with us, this winter, delving
away at things bacterial;
otherwise, I should have been dis-
tressed beyond degree to hear
that you were not in a
16 to 1 condition! you probably
voted for the wrong man!
However, your poverty, though
very pleasing, did not give
me that excess of delight
which followed the knowledge
that I had sown a little
seed thatwhich had “fallen in good
ground”! I think Mrs. Kean's
expression to Martha that “her
feelings were sticking out
on all sides like pseudo=
pods”, has given me more
real happiness and general
comfort than anything that
has happened during the last
twenty years! Although pseu=
dopods are not pointed, the ex=
pression was so much to the point
and so picturesque and
so illustrative of the general
tendency on the part of your
dear lady to blend the scientific
with the every day affairs of
life, that the mind feels buoy=
-ed up and more hopeful
of the ultimate conversion
of the world to science!
Not that Martha, the dear
little creature, was really
irritable - that would be
impossible, unless she inherits
a slight tendency in that di=
rection from some great,
great grandfather! In all
probability, a mosquito was
secretedly knawing at her
vitals and this was only a
2)
WAR DEPARTMENT,
SURGEON GENERAL'S OFFICE,
ARMY MEDICAL MUSEUM AND LIBRARY,
WASHINGTON.
slight reflex response to
some hidden irritation!
I did not endorse at all
what you said about Dr
Cleau Dommini's introduction
to the fruit of Heaven! I don't
see that he has done such
great things as to be entitled
to this ecstatic bliss! No,
honestly, I'd see him d-d
before he or any body else
should even as much as
look upon that joy-compelling
food, if I were King!!

However, you know my
sentiments, on this subject, and that I would ex=
clude from that excess of pun-
ishment, above mentioned, my
particular friends at Key West!
The S. G. did say that the change
in your station would be
made “in the spring”- Perhaps
he meant during the Key West-
ian spring, which I suppose
begins in January. I doubt
not that you will arrive at
the “Hub”, at just about the
season when the buds are
enlarging and the little birds
are beginning to call each other
from the half-verdant tree-tops.
And with the accumulated
gold of some half year in
your breeches pocket, what
a “galorious” time you and your
charming lady will have! I
really envy you!

your friend, Col.
Bache, was President of our
Board. I gave him your mes-
sage which he was very glad
to receive - evidently remembers
you very kindly - Indeed, he paid
you some compliments which
I shall withhold - He is a very
agreeable gentleman and im=
pressed us all favorably - I am
so sorry, my dear Doctor, that I can=
not send you the questions to which
you refer. The law requires that
they shall all be destroyed in the
presence of the Board - very silly
requirement, but true. I will
only say that they embraced all
that is contained in the Practice
of Med.& Surgery & Hygiane, both
ancient and modern! During all
of October we struggled with the help-
less candidates who presented
themselves, and at last called out
eight. The wretches! I hear them
this very minute, as they rattle
the plates & test-tubes across
the Hall, in frantic efforts to
isolate the wily bacillus in
pure culture! They will yet
be the death of me! With these in
the mornings and Fitz. Carter & Arthur
in the afternoons, my hands are
full. Do you wonder that I neglect
my best friends? Mrs. Reed joins me
in kindest regards to Mr. Kean & your-
self - for myself, I don't send “regards”
but my best love to both of you, not
forgetting dear little Martha. Please write
again.
